audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker welcoming listeners to a tutorial. He announces that he will demonstrate how to upgrade from Windows 8 to Windows 10, describing the process as "very simple" and "very straightforward." He promises the upgrade process will handle data and hard drive partitioning automatically. The speaker then declares that he will prove he doesn't already have Windows 10 before the clip cuts to the sound of a whoosh.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker discussing Windows 8.1 and the Start Menu, then transitions to describing how to access the Control Panel via apps, searching for "Control Panel." He then explains navigating to System and Security, and then System, to view system information. He notes the processor type and installed memory. The speaker mentions it's a "64-bit operating system".

The audio clip consists of one male speaker explaining the implications of upgrading to Windows 10 in terms of bit architecture, saying, "When you upgrade to Windows 10... you're going to have 64-bit Windows 10 if you had 64-bit Windows 8 to begin with." He goes on to say that if you started with 32-bit Windows 8, you will have 32-bit Windows 10. He is speaking in an explanatory, instructional tone.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker providing instructions on how to access a software download. He suggests using the provided website. The speaker then suggests that a link will be included in the description. Next, a "download now" button will be pressed and this is followed by the completion of the step. This step then leads to the "execution" of the program and the browser can be closed. After closing the browser, the speaker mentions that it will take some time for the program to start. He also describes the "Windows 10 font" and "Windows 10 colors". He explains that the system files, programs, and files won't be erased, rather, the operating system will undergo an "easy upgrade".

The audio clip starts with a single male speaker who says, "will eventually go to the next window" then, "and that window looks like this."  He proceeds, explaining "these are the basic terms". The same male speaker continues, instructing the listener that they can "not need to read through those, just go ahead and click accept".

The audio clip starts with one male speaker discussing concerns about product keys, particularly with Windows 8 and 8.1, and how Windows 10 simplifies the activation process by using the existing key. The speaker clarifies that you no longer need to find or remember your product key, because it communicates with Microsoft to validate itself. He confirms this has happened to him before, emphasizing that he never needed to know his product key. The clip ends with an indistinct sound.

The clip begins with one male speaker providing computer instructions, saying things like "you come to this window here" and "what you want to do." He explains the upgrade process from Windows 8 to Windows 10, differentiating between upgrading the current PC versus changing architectures or installing on another computer. He concludes by selecting "upgrade this PC now" and mentions the screen will pause for a bit. Finally, a computer mouse click is heard.

The clip begins with a male speaker describing what to do if your computer doesn't have enough space for the installation process, saying to "remove some files". He suggests that you can download them or "install them again later". He then recommends using the "free up disk space" feature to clean up unnecessary files. Next, there is a brief, unidentifiable sound effect. The speaker then says "All right".

The clip features a single male speaker explaining that if there is at least 8 gigabytes of free space on the PC, the download process will begin, which will take some time. He then suggests skipping through this part. We then hear the speaker say that the download took him about 30 minutes and that the user can still use the PC while it downloads, implying that someone does not need to remain idle. There is a "click" sound somewhere in between the sentences that may be a mouse click or a similar sound.

The audio features one speaker, who is male. First, he states that he will now perform a "verifying procedure" that will take a "decent amount of time." He then says, "At some point during this process it's gonna switch over to saying it's creating Windows 10 media, not to be alarmed. That's the same thing." He later states that the process is finished and that the computer will clean up, and then shut off. Next he comments that he will switch over to his phone. This transitions into the sound of clicking, followed by a bootup sound of a computer. The speaker then returns, saying that the computer will "quickly check for updates" and "check for PC, it's getting a few things ready before it starts to boot from Windows 10 media".

A male speaker expresses frustration at having to sign another set of licenses and verifies that a product key works. He then notes that the system is checking for updates, which Windows tends to do often. Next, he describes how the system is making sure that it is ready to install, but no progress is shown. He mentions that waiting is needed, with processor speed impacting the wait time. Following that, the system is making sure the computer has enough space, but it turns out more space is needed for the update. The speaker highlights that the system provides options to free up more space, and that more space is needed to download and install the update. He inserts a flash drive with enough space, confirms the drive, and continues the update. The speaker wants a smooth and easy process, as the computer will not be used after this.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker explaining that he will stop the video and switch over to his phone. He states, "let's begin". The speaker then describes what occurred after he pressed "install," indicating that he can no longer use the phone, and that Windows 10 is installing for real. He mentions that the phone will restart several times during the process and that this is normal. He says, "this might take a while", and will check back in when it is almost finished. After the first restart, the phone will start installing some updates and, as the warning says, to not turn the pc off.

The clip starts with a male speaker, speaking in an instructional tone about a Windows 10 loading screen. He says, "once everything's good to go... you're going to see this loading screen... minimal sign-in things... working with Windows 10." He emphasizes how easy it is, ensuring that all files remain intact and that nothing has been moved. He concludes by saying "Thanks so much for watching. This is Falconator signing out." Subsequently, a soft "thump" sound effect is heard, immediately followed by a brief, pleasant-sounding jingle.
